review.title: Causes for Query Answers from Databases, Datalog Abduction and View-Updates: The Presence of Integrity Constraints
review.abstract: Causality has been recently introduced in databases, to model, characterize and possibly compute causes for query results (answers). Connections between queryanswer causality, consistency-based diagnosis, database repairs (wrt. integrity constraint violations), abductive diagnosis and the view-update problem have been established. In this work we further investigate connections between query-answer causality and abductive diagnosis and the view-update problem. In this context, we also define and investigate the notion of query-answer causality in the presence of integrity constraints.

sections.text: Links have been established between the causality of the query-response, consistency-based diagnosis, database repairs (violation of integrity limitations), abductive diagnosis and the view-update problem. In this paper, we will further investigate relationships between the causality of the query-response and the abductive diagnosis, as well as the view-update problem. In this context, we will also define and examine the concept of the causality of the query-response causality in the presence of integrity limitations.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions
sections.text: Combined with the results reported in [Salimi & Bertossi, 2015a], we can see that there are deeper and more diverse connections between the areas of QA causality, abductive and consistency-based diagnosis, view updates and database repairs. Abduction has also been explicitly applied to database repairs [Arieli et al., 2004]. The idea, in turn, is to "hijack" possible repair updates that bring the database into a consistent state. Links between consistency-based and abductive diagnosis have been established, e.g. in [Console & Torasso, 1991].
